Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: MAKER: Nebraska Innovative Maker Co-laboratory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM). The project will design, develop and test a Makerspace engagement model that connects geographically dispersed learning communities and mentors participating in Maker activities and spaces to provide informal STEM learning pathways and to broaden participation for STEM activities for youth and their community. The project will establish a dedicated public library-based Makerspace in a rural, relatively isolated and underserved community with close connections to an anchor space at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln that supports open-ended, self-directed learning, idea exploration, technical skills, entrepreneurship, and collaborative projects. The project design will bring together experts from a wide variety of fields (e.g., engineering, textiles, photography, robotics, and STEM education) to provide youth with hands-on opportunities in six focus areas, electronics, textiles including e-textiles with wearable electronics, computers, digital media creation, music technology, and digital fabrication.  Youth will select a project and learning pathway based on their interests. Youth will then complete mini-courses and receive certification on the equipment and skills relevant to their chosen project. The expected synergy between virtual collaborative spaces and robotic telepresence will provide opportunities for teams of youth and mentors to collaborate regardless of geographic location and to creatively collaborate, problem solve and innovate. (Telepresence robots are defined as platforms that allow users to perceive that they are operating in another, typically remote physical space via technology.)  

This project focuses on using two main strategies; a) virtual collaborative spaces and b) robotic telepresence, to provide rural youth access to the Maker movement. This model will provide a replicable strategy of reaching rural underserved youth audiences within their communities so that they may establish wider learning communities with experts and mentors and thereby fully participate in the maker experience. The use of telepresence robotics for focused one-on-one collaboration and guidance in the Makerspace will particularly help to address the physical needs of such mentoring. Virtual innovative lab spaces will allow youth to develop project ideas and engage in collaborative problem solving. The spaces will be accessible via mobile phone based Head-Mounted Displays. Student surveys, observation, social network analysis, and the systematic coding of interactions between youth and mentors will be used to research the nature of the collaboration, problem solving and innovation that occurs through shared making activities.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Nebraska Innovative Maker Co-laboratory (NiMC)project which promoted a model of connectedness and social innovation with the maker movement was led by Nebraska Extension, with Co-Principal Investigators from UNL's Innovation Studio, UNL College of Engineering, the College of Education at the University of Nebraska at Omaha, and the Nebraska Library Commission. Geographic distance in Nebraska is one of the largest barriers to student participation in Makerspaces, and this issue is compounded further by a general lack of mentors in these areas who have the skills necessary to lead and guide communities of learners.  For the grant, the project team researched makerspaces using two main strategies; immersive virtual collaborative spaces and robotic telepresence, to provide rural audiences access to the Maker movement. The model provided a replicable strategy of reaching rural underserved youth audiences within their communities so that they may establish wider learning communities with experts and mentors and thereby fully participate in the maker experience.    

The Sidney makerspace was fully set up in December of 2017 and included an Epilog Laser Cutter, Carvey CNC router, MakerBot Replicator + 3D printer, a digital video and audio studio, a Circuit Vinyl cutter, Juki HZL-F600 computerized sewing and quilting machine, and a HUE Animation Studio complete stop motion animation kit.  In addition, a telepresence robot was installed at the Sidney Library as well as at the Nebraska Innovation Studio (NIS) in Lincoln, Nebraska to operationalize the planned telepresence environment for that site.  In year two of the project a second temporary site was located in Columbus, Nebraska.

Overall the project developed a technological model that led to the successful formation of extended learning communities regardless of geographical distance and access to the physical Makerspace using telepresence robotics and Immersive Virtual Reality. The telepresence robot used in the project was the Suitable Technologies BEAM and over 500 calls were made during the project with a total connection time of 269 hours, or an average of 13.45 hours per month from 7 different pilots.  In addition, the project developed and tested a number of processes for using VR for digital creation and collaboration.   In addition, the project developed an introductory activity for youth to collaboratively design a bubble wand in Masterpiece VR and subsequently send the file to a 3D printer. The activity was piloted and refined with school students at Nebraska Innovation Studio.  As an example of the process, in the bubble wand activity, youth were coached on how to use the software, provided a brief lesson on creative thinking in Facebook Spaces, and then provided time to design a bubble wand using MasterPiece VR.  Once completed the file was saved and printed on the MakerBot Replicator + 3D printer a process we referred to as the digital to physical manifestation.

 

Students that participated in the project's research study were drawn from two Nebraska school districts: Sidney (n = 19) and Columbus Scotus (n = 38).  Students were drawn from grades 9 – 12, with the average age of participant 16.13. 72% were male and 26% were female. Results showed increases in problem-solving/creativity, making, and confidence.  In addition, a social network analysis (SNA) was conducted to examine the extent to which relationships were formed between the students and the UNL personnel and classroom teachers.  Overall, the analysis indicated increases in the density of interactions indicating the use of a telepresence robot increased interactions within the remote maker sites.    Specifically, interaction levels for the overall network, the density of interaction level 1 reduced from 63.2% to 47.6% which means that the density of students responding "I have never met this person (I have no idea who they are)" decreased by 15.6%.  The density of interaction level 2 increased from 6.50% to 13.0% which means that the density of students responding "I know who this person is but haven't had a conversation with them" increased in density by 6.50%.  The density of interaction level 3 increased from 26.4% to 28.1% which means the density of students responding "I have asked this person for help while working on schoolwork/projects" increased by 1.70%.  The density of interaction level 4 increased from 3.90% to 11.3% which means the density of students responding "I have asked this person for personal advice which could include my future or well-being" increased by 7.40%.  

The NiMC project successfully developed and tested a replicable model using telepresence robotics and immersive VR technologies to bring the maker movement to underserved rural communities and youth audiences.  Project resources are available online at https://nimc.unl.edu.

Modified by: Bradley S Barker

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Nebraska Innovative Maker Co-laboratory (NiMC)project which promoted a model of connectedness and social innovation with the maker movement was led by Nebraska Extension, with Co-Principal Investigators from UNL's Innovation Studio, UNL College of Engineering, the College of Education at the University of Nebraska at Omaha, and the Nebraska Library Commission. Geographic distance in Nebraska is one of the largest barriers to student participation in Makerspaces, and this issue is compounded further by a general lack of mentors in these areas who have the skills necessary to lead and guide communities of learners. For the grant, the project team researched makerspaces using two main strategies; immersive virtual collaborative spaces and robotic telepresence, to provide rural audiences access to the Maker movement. The model provided a replicable strategy of reaching rural underserved youth audiences within their communities so that they may establish wider learning communities with experts and mentors and thereby fully participate in the maker experience. The Sidney makerspace was fully set up in December of 2017 and included an Epilog Laser Cutter, Carvey CNC router, MakerBot Replicator + 3D printer, a digital video and audio studio, a Circuit Vinyl cutter, Juki HZL-F600 computerized sewing and quilting machine, and a HUE Animation Studio complete stop motion animation kit. In addition, a telepresence robot was installed at the Sidney Library as well as at the Nebraska Innovation Studio (NIS) in Lincoln, Nebraska to operationalize the planned telepresence environment for that site. In year two of the project a second temporary site was located in Columbus, Nebraska. Overall the project developed a technological model that led to the successful formation of extended learning communities regardless of geographical distance and access to the physical Makerspace using telepresence robotics and Immersive Virtual Reality. The telepresence robot used in the project was the Suitable Technologies BEAM and over 500 calls were made during the project with a total connection time of 269 hours, or an average of 13.45 hours per month from 7 different pilots. In addition, the project developed and tested a number of processes for using VR for digital creation and collaboration. In addition, the project developed an introductory activity for youth to collaboratively design a bubble wand in Masterpiece VR and subsequently send the file to a 3D printer. The activity was piloted and refined with school students at Nebraska Innovation Studio. As an example of the process, in the bubble wand activity, youth were coached on how to use the software, provided a brief lesson on creative thinking in Facebook Spaces, and then provided time to design a bubble wand using MasterPiece VR. Once completed the file was saved and printed on the MakerBot Replicator + 3D printer a process we referred to as the digital to physical manifestation. Students that participated in the project's research study were drawn from two Nebraska school districts: Sidney (n = 19) and Columbus Scotus (n = 38). Students were drawn from grades 9 – 12, with the average age of participant 16.13. 72% were male and 26% were female. Results showed increases in problem-solving/creativity, making, and confidence. In addition, a social network analysis (SNA) was conducted to examine the extent to which relationships were formed between the students and the UNL personnel and classroom teachers. Overall, the analysis indicated increases in the density of interactions indicating the use of a telepresence robot increased interactions within the remote maker sites. Specifically, interaction levels for the overall network, the density of interaction level 1 reduced from 63.2% to 47.6% which means that the density of students responding "I have never met this person (I have no idea who they are)" decreased by 15.6%. The density of interaction level 2 increased from 6.50% to 13.0% which means that the density of students responding "I know who this person is but haven't had a conversation with them" increased in density by 6.50%. The density of interaction level 3 increased from 26.4% to 28.1% which means the density of students responding "I have asked this person for help while working on schoolwork/projects" increased by 1.70%. The density of interaction level 4 increased from 3.90% to 11.3% which means the density of students responding "I have asked this person for personal advice which could include my future or well-being" increased by 7.40%. The NiMC project successfully developed and tested a replicable model using telepresence robotics and immersive VR technologies to bring the maker movement to underserved rural communities and youth audiences. Project resources are available online at https://nimc.unl.edu. Last Modified: 06/21/2019 Submitted by: Bradley S Barker
